Technical Assistance Subproject Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 52194-005  
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (C-KSTA) 
December 2018 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Policy Research on 
Ecological Protection and Rural Vitalization for 
Supporting Green Development in the Yangtze River 
Economic Belt 
 
 
 
Subproject 4: Policy Research on Sustainable Forestry in 
the Yangtze River Economic Belt 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s

KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE 
I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT  1 
A.  Overall Progress of the TA cluster  1 
B.  Subproject Outcome  1 
C.  Subproject Outputs, Methods, and Activities  1 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing  2 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements  2 
 
APPENDIXES  
1.  Subproject Design and Monitoring Framework  4 
2.  Subproject Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  7 
3.  List of Linked Documents  8

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
A.  Overall Progress of the TA cluster 
1.  The knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA) cluster  was  approved  on  15 
September 2018. The overall TA cluster is estimated at $1.5 million. The TA subproject 1 was 
approved on 15 October 2018, while the TA subprojects 2 and 3 were approved on 23 November 
2018 and 13 November 2018, respectively. The subproject is estimated to cost $350,000 and will 
be financed on a grant basis from the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The Ecological Institute of the Forestry Industry Planning 
and Design Institute (EIFIPDI) of the State Forestry and Grassland Administration (SFGA) under 
the Ministry of Natural Resources will serve as the executing and implementing agency of the 
subproject. The design and monitoring framework of the subproject is in Appendix 1.1 
 
B.  Subproject Outcome 
2.   The subproject will have the following outcome: capacity and institutional framework for 
equitable and inclusive sustainable forestry policies and programs enhanced. This will support 
the outputs of the overall TA cluster by contributing to an enabling environment for ecological 
compensation, innovative financing mechanisms for ecosystem protection, as well as knowledge 
sharing and dissemination. The subproject will be aligned with the following impact: green 
economic development and ecological protection in the Yangtze River Economic Belt (YREB) 
achieved. The SFGA is committed to undertaking a policy research on equitable and inclusive 
sustainable forestry in the YREB. To achieve this, EIFIPDI requested ADB’s support for the 
outputs outlined below. 
 
C.  Subproject Outputs, Methods, and Activities   
3.  Output 1: Assessment of the status and prospects for the commercial forestry 
sector in the YREB prepared. This will include (i) a summary of the current status of the 
commercial forestry in the YREB including timber and bamboo production, non-timber forest 
products, and agroforestry, including identification of key commercial forestry areas in the YREB, 
estimates of annual production, structure of output, assessment of the size and contributions of 
state-owned, collective, and private household forestry to total production, measures of industry 
concentration  ratio,  and  estimates  of  changes  over  time  in  all  of  these  indicators;  (ii)  an 
assessment of the future prospects of the commercial forestry sector in the YREB including 
estimated future demand in the People’s Republic of China and globally, and the capacity of 
current and future commercial forestry operations in the YREB to sustainably meet the current 
and estimated future demand; and (iii) a summary of current programs and policies targeting the 
development  and  management  of  the  commercial  forestry  and  agroforestry  sectors,  an 
assessment of their impacts and remaining legal and regulatory gaps and market failures to 
realizing sustainable and profitable commercial forestry and agroforestry sectors.  
4.  Output 2: Assessment of the status and current and future threats to forest and 
wetlands ecosystem conservation in the YREB prepared. This will include (i) a mapping and 
categorization of forest and wetlands ecosystem types in the YREB and a prioritization of the 
threats they face; (ii) a summary of current programs and policies targeting forest and wetlands 
conservation and restoration in the YREB, and an assessment of their ecological and rural welfare 
impacts; (iii) a prioritization of forest and wetlands conservation targets in the YREB; and (iv) an 
                                                
1 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 October 2018.

2 
assessment of current regulatory gaps and funding requirements and shortfalls for realizing 
sustainable conservation and/or restoration of key forest and wetlands ecosystems in the YREB. 
5.  Output 3: Policy brief providing detailed recommendations to the government on 
the  potential  to  achieving  equitable  and  inclusive  sustainable  forestry  in  the  YREB 
developed. This will include (i) a summary of relevant international best practice regarding 
policies and approaches to achieving equitable and inclusive sustainable forestry; (ii) site visits to 
consult with local administrators, with weighting towards key ecological function zones in the 
YREB, regarding their constraints and perspectives on different forestry policy approaches; (iii) a 
survey and analysis, with weighting towards key ecological function zones in the YREB, to assess 
rural household income, income sources, and household constraints and preferences regarding 
different program interventions to achieve sustainable forestry outcomes, including possible 
commercial forestry and agroforestry options; and (iv) preparation of final policy recommendations 
based on Outputs 1 and 2 and the rural survey and local administrator consultations, for cost-
effectively realizing the integration of equitable and inclusive sustainable forestry in the YREB. 
This includes a ranking of different policy and program options along various dimensions based 
the previous analyses, a prioritization of interventions and locations based on the conservation 
threats assessment and the commercial forestry sector analysis, and recommendations regarding 
which legal and regulatory gaps and barriers are most important to address.  
6.  Output  4:  National  and  international  knowledge  dissemination  and  sharing  of 
subproject findings conducted. This will include (i) organization of various working group 
meetings in the People’s Republic of China targeting government officials administering key 
ecological function zones and other conservation forestry areas in the YREB, to share a summary 
of the findings of Outputs 1–3, and to obtain feedback and current challenges; (ii) presentation of 
these findings in selected domestic and international workshops and conferences hosted by other 
ADB member countries; (iii) development of 2–5 brief news items, articles or blogs on subproject 
findings, and publishing these on various international platforms such as Development Asia; and 
(iv) development of a knowledge product summarizing findings from Outputs 1–3. 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
7.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $380,000, of which $350,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  TASF-other  sources.  The  key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
8.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, other administrative assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
9.  The  Environment,  Natural  Resources,  and  Agriculture  Division  of  ADB’s  East  Asia 
Department will administer the Subproject 4 of the TA cluster, particularly on the selection, 
supervision, and evaluation of the TA consultants. 
 
10.  EIFIPDI will be the executing and implementing agency and will provide oversight, ensure 
coordination across sectors, and provide guidance to the implementation. A comprehensive 
project management office will be established in EIFIPDI. The project management office will be 
the main contact point for ADB and will provide oversight and liaison with the districts and counties. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

3

11.  Consulting  services.  It  is  estimated  that  the  TA  will  require  30  person-months  of 
consulting services, comprising at least one international and four national consultants which will 
be selected using individual consultant selection method. Areas of expertise required will include 
environmental economics, forestry economics, agricultural economics, ecology and hydrology. 
The  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as 
amended from time to time) and the associated staff instructions.2 
 
12.  Office equipment will be procured by request for quotation method under two contract 
packages.3 Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time).
                                                
2 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
3 Procurement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Assessment of the status and prospects for the commercial forestry sector in the YREB 
prepared  
1.1 Summarize the status of the commercial forestry in the YREB (Q1 2019–Q3 2019)  
1.2 Assess the prospects of the commercial forestry sector in the YREB (Q1 2019–Q3 2019)  
1.3 Summarize current programs and policies targeting the development and management of the 
commercial forestry and agroforestry sectors (Q1 2019–Q3 2019)  
 
2.  Assessment of the status and current and future threats to forest and wetlands ecosystem 
conservation in the YREB prepared  
2.1 Map and categorize forest and wetlands ecosystem types and prioritize the threats they face (Q1 
2019–Q3 2019) 
2.2 Summarize current programs and policies targeting forest and wetlands conservation and restoration 
in the YREB, and assess their ecological and rural welfare impacts (Q1 2019–Q3 2019) 
2.3 Prioritize forest and wetlands conservation targets in the YREB (Q1 2019–Q3 2019) 
2.4 Assess current regulatory gaps and funding requirements and shortfalls for realizing sustainable 
conservation and/or restoration of key forest and wetlands ecosystems in the YREB  
      (Q1 2019–Q3 2019)

6  Appendix 1 
3.  Policy brief providing detailed recommendations to the national government on the potential to 
achieving equitable and inclusive sustainable forestry in the YREB developed  
3.1 Summarize international best practice regarding policies and approaches to achieving sustainable 
forestry (Q1 2019–Q3 2019) 
3.2 Conduct site visits to consult with local administrators (Q2 2019–Q3 2019)   
3.3 Conduct rural household survey and analysis (Q2 2019–Q2 2020) 
3.4 Prepare final policy recommendations, based on Outputs 1 and 2 and the rural survey and local 
administrator consultations (Q4 2019–Q2 2020)  
 
4.  National and international knowledge dissemination and sharing of subproject findings 
conducted 
4.1 Organize various workshops or group meetings in the PRC targeting government officials 
administering key ecological function zones and other conservation forestry areas  
      (Q3 2019–Q2 2020)   
4.2 Present the research findings in domestic and international workshops and conferences, especially 
those hosted by other developing member countries (Q1 2020–Q2 2020) 
4.3 Develop 2–5 brief news items, articles or blogs on subproject findings, and publishing of these on 
various international platforms (Q3 2019–Q2 2020) 
4.4 Develop knowledge product summarizing findings for Outputs 1–3 (Q1 2020–Q2 2020)

LIST OF LINKED DOCUMENTS 
http://www.adb.org/Documents/LinkedDocs/?id=52194-005-TAReport 
 
1.  Terms of Reference for Consultants 
2.   Procurement Plan

Policy Research on Sustainable Forestry in the Yangtze River Economic Belt 
(KSTA PRC 52194-005) 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  engage  consultants  using  the  individual 
consultant selection method. It is estimated that the technical assistance (TA) will require 30 
person-months of consulting services, comprising at least one international and four national 
consultants. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated staff instructions. 
B.  Terms of Reference 
2.  Environmental economist and team leader (international, 5.0 person-months). The 
economist and team leader must be fluent in English and ideally will have (i) a postgraduate 
degree in environmental economics or other relevant field; and (ii) 8 or more years of research 
experience  in  environmental  management,  sustainable  forest  management,  and  forest 
economics. Work experience in international organizations is highly desired. The consultant will 
be responsible for (i) working with the deputy team leader to coordinate and manage all subproject 
activities, timelines, and delivery of outputs; (ii) conducting a literature review of international best 
practice regarding equitable and inclusive sustainable forestry; (iii) leading work to formulate the 
rural survey strategy, methodology and design, and to conduct quantitative analysis of the survey 
data; (iv) providing technical support and peer review for the forestry economic and ecological 
assessments; (v) working with other experts to develop the final policy recommendations; (vi) 
drafting and finalizing 2–5 brief news items or articles for international dissemination; (vii) drafting 
and finalizing a knowledge product summarizing subproject findings and recommendations; and 
(viii) presenting subproject findings, when appropriate, at international venues, conferences and 
workshops.    
3.  Forestry  economist  and  deputy  team  leader  (national,  9.0  person-months).  The 
economist  and  deputy  team  leader  must  be  fluent  in  English  and  ideally  will  have  (i)  a 
postgraduate degree in forestry economics, environmental economics, or other relevant field; and 
(ii) 8 or more years of research experience in sustainable forest management, agroforestry, and 
forest economics. Work experience in international organizations is highly desired. The consultant 
will be responsible for (i) working with the team leader to coordinate and manage all subproject 
activities, timelines, and delivery of outputs; (ii) leading work to develop the assessment of the 
status and prospects for the commercial forestry and agroforestry sectors in the Yangtze River 
Economic  Belt  (YREB);  (iii)  working  with  the  environmental  economist  and  development 
economist to develop the strategy, methodology, and design of the rural survey and conduct 
quantitative  analysis  of  the  survey  data;  (iv)  working  with  the  development  economist  to 
coordinate and conduct the consultations with local officials and to implement the rural survey; (v) 
working with the forest and wetlands ecologist and hydrologist to develop an assessment of 
current  regulatory  gaps  and  funding  requirements  and  shortfalls  for  realizing  sustainable 
conservation and/or restoration of key forest and wetlands ecosystems in the YREB; and (vi) 
working with other consultants to develop the final policy recommendations. 
4.  Development economist (national, 8.0 person-months). The economist must be fluent in 
English and ideally will have (i) a postgraduate degree in development economics, economics, or 
other relevant fields; and (ii) 8 or more years of research experience in development and 
sustainable forest management and agroforestry. Work experience in international organizations 
is highly desired. The consultant will be responsible for (i) working with the forestry economist to 
develop the assessment of the status and prospects for the commercial forestry and agroforestry

sectors in the YREB; (ii) leading work in summarizing current programs and policies targeting 
forest and wetlands conservation and restoration in the YREB and assessing their rural welfare 
impacts; (iii) working with the forestry economist and environmental economist to develop the 
strategy, methodology and design of the rural survey, and to conduct quantitative analysis of the 
survey data; (iv) working with the forestry economist to coordinate and conduct the consultations 
with local officials and to implement the rural survey; and (v) working with other consultants to 
develop the final policy recommendations. 
5.  Forest and wetlands ecologist (national, 5.0 person-months). The ecologist must be 
fluent in English and ideally will have (i) a postgraduate degree in forestry, ecology, or other 
relevant fields; and (ii) 8 or more years of research experience in forest and wetlands conservation 
and  management.  Work  experience  in  international  organizations  is  highly  desired.  The 
consultant will be responsible for (i) leading work to develop a mapping of forest and wetland 
ecosystem types and distribution in the YREB, and an assessment of the threats they face; (ii) 
leading work to develop a prioritization of key forestry and wetlands conservation targets in the 
YREB; (iii) working with the  development economist and hydrologist to  summarize current 
programs and policies targeting forest and wetlands conservation and restoration in the YREB, 
and to assess their ecological impacts; (iv) working with the hydrologist and forestry economist to 
develop an assessment of current regulatory gaps and funding requirements and shortfalls for 
realizing sustainable conservation and/or restoration of key forest and wetlands ecosystems in 
the YREB; and (v) working with other consultants to develop the final policy recommendations.  
6.  Hydrologist (national, 3.0 person-months). The hydrologist must be fluent in English and 
ideally will have (i) a postgraduate degree in hydrology or other relevant fields; and (ii) 8 or more 
years  of  research  experience  in  ecohydrology  and  forest  hydrology.  Work  experience  in 
international organizations is highly desired. The consultant will be responsible for (i) working with 
the forest and wetlands ecologist to develop a mapping of forest and wetland ecosystem types 
and distribution in the YREB, and an assessment of the threats they face; (ii) working with the 
forest and wetlands ecologist to develop a prioritization of key forestry and wetlands conservation 
targets in the YREB; (iii) working with the development economist and the forest and wetlands 
ecologist to summarize current programs and policies targeting forest and wetlands conservation 
and restoration in the YREB, and to assess their ecological impacts; (iv) leading work to develop 
an assessment of current regulatory gaps and funding requirements and shortfalls for realizing 
sustainable conservation and/or restoration of key forest and wetlands ecosystems in the YREB; 
and (v) working with other consultants to develop the final policy recommendations.  
C.  Reporting 
7.  All documents will be submitted in both English and Chinese languages to the executing 
agency and ADB in hard and electronic copies. The final outputs will be posted on the ADB 
website in both languages.

Policy Research on Sustainable Forestry in the Yangtze River Economic Belt 
(KSTA PRC 52194-005)
